Dear Ms. Shillings:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer, at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not follow agency policy to maintain line of sight. While
out of sight one youth physically assaulted another.
Investigation On 7/12/24 Chief Administrator reported to DCWL that during
the evening of 7/11/24 Youth A walked into the lounge area, while
Youth B was alone in there. Youth A then put Youth B in a choke
hold and held him until he was unconscious and fell to the floor.
When Youth B fell, he split his chin and lip, and broke a tooth.
Youth B was taken to the hospital. Staff 1 did not appropriately
intervene when Youth A walked into the lounge. Staff 1 was aware
youth were not to be in the room alone together. Staff 1 was
terminated.
On 7/15/24 a face-to-face interview was completed with Chief
Administrator in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Chief
Administrator stated that Youth A initially indicated the injuries to
Youth B were caused by “horse play”. However, Chief
Administrator reviewed the video and could clearly see that was
inaccurate. Youth B was moved to another floor of the facility, to
prevent contact with Youth A. Youth A is also placed on one-to-
one supervision and staff have been instructed that he is not to be
within ten feet of Youth B at any time. Nor will the youth travel
together for any reason. Chief Administrator told staff they will lose
their job if this safety plan is not followed.
Chief Administrator stated she spoke with the local police
department and they were unwilling to accept a report unless it
came directly from Youth B. Youth B was in the hospital at the
time. Law Enforcement was also unwilling to review the video or
photos of Youth B’s injuries.
2

Chief Administrator stated that Youth B had difficulty recalling
what happened. Youth A was attempting to gaslight Youth B by
telling everyone it was an accident, and they were just playing.
Chief Administrator reported there were no incidents earlier in the
day between the two youth that would have predicted this assault.
Chief Administrator reported a 30-day notice was in place to have
Youth A removed from the facility.
On 7/15/24 a face-to-face interview with Staff 3 was completed in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported he was on
duty on 7/11/24 as a one-to-one staff with another youth. Staff 3
did not see the alleged incident, nor was he aware of any
situations between Youth A and Youth B that would have triggered
the incident.
On 7/15/24 a face-to-face interview with Youth B was completed
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B was observed to
have sutures on his chin and lip. Youth B also has a chipped front
tooth. Youth B could not recall any staff or peers that were present
during the incident. However, Youth B stated that he remembered
he was supposed to be in his room at the time of the incident, but
he was restless and pacing the area. Youth B recalled staff telling
him to go to his room several times.
Youth B stated that on 7/11/24, while in the lounge, Youth A
walked up behind him and stated they needed to talk. Youth A
then put Youth B in a choke hold. Youth B thought Youth A was
playing around at first. But then Youth A squeezed his neck harder
and Youth B realized he was serious. Youth B hit Youth A's arm,
but did not remember much after that, as he passed out. Youth B
was told he hit the floor with his face. Youth B recalled going to
the hospital for medical attention. Youth B stated that his jaw
really hurt and he was prescribed Tylenol and antibiotics. Youth
B’s jaw was x-rayed twice and they determined it was not broken.
Youth B stated he did not have any major issues with Youth A and
the situation was a misunderstanding. Youth A believed Youth B
had his contraband phone, but he did not. Youth A has since
apologized to Youth B.
Youth B stated he and Youth A have been in fights before, but not
to this extent and not recently. They sometimes “play fight” and
have a “love/hate” relationship with one another.
On 7/15/24 DCWL and MDHHS Worker attempted a face-to-face
interview with Youth A. Youth A refused and said that everything
he needed to say about the incident was in his written statement.
3

On 7/15/24 a face-to-face interview with Youth C was completed
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported that he
heard about the incident with Youth A and Youth B, but he did not
see it happen. Youth C heard coughing, then yelling and ran into
the lounge, where he saw Youth B on the floor with blood coming
out of his mouth. Youth C stated Youth A and Youth B usually got
along, although he witnessed them fighting before. Youth C
reported that he was punched by Youth A once a few weeks ago.
Youth C stated that he believed Youth A was homicidal. Youth C
stated that Youth A was never in trouble with the police when
these things happen, so Youth A thinks he will never get in
trouble. Youth C was asked if he felt safe with Youth A at the
facility. Youth C stated he did not know how to answer that
question.
On 7/15/24 a face-to-face interview with Youth D was completed
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth D reported that he
was on the unit at the time but did not witness the incident. Youth
D stated he did not hear Youth A and Youth B arguing or fighting
prior to the incident. Youth D stated he had witnessed how Youth
A could be aggressive at times when upset.
On 8/9/24 a face-to-face interview with Supervisor was
completed by DCWL. Supervisor confirmed that she was on duty
on the night of 7/11/24. Supervisor did not witness the incident.
However, she did see Youth B after the incident. Staff 1 told
Supervisor what occurred and indicated Youth A assaulted Youth
B. Staff 1 was visibly shaken by the incident. Supervisor called
911 and an ambulance transported Youth B to the hospital.
Supervisor had not watched the video at the time of the interview.
Supervisor confirmed that Youth A and Youth B should have been
in their rooms at the time of the incident and should not have been
alone together in the lounge. Staff 1 was positioned at the lounge
door and therefore knew both youth were in there. Staff 1 should
have redirected the youth to their rooms and kept them in line of
sight until they complied. If Staff 1 was struggling with this, she
should have called on the radio for assistance.
On 8/9/24 a video conference was held with Foster Care Worker.
Foster Care Worker reported the plan was to move Youth A from
the facility, as he was not appropriate to be there. However, they
received denials for each placement contacted thus far. Youth A
was previously in several situations where criminal charges should
have occurred but did not. Foster Care Worker indicated that prior
to this incident, while at another placement, Youth A made threats
4

to a school and physically assaulted people. Youth A continued
these behaviors as he was never held accountable for his actions.
Foster Care Worker stated that the court will likely intervene to
escalate Youth A to a secure placement. Foster Care Worker
reported that Law Enforcement and the Prosecutor’s office were
contacted regarding the incident with Youth B. It was unknown if
charges would be filed.
On 8/20/24 Staff 1 was interviewed by MDHHS Worker. DCWL
made an attempt to interview Staff 1 on 8/22/24. However, she
declined, stating that she no longer worked at the facility and
already spoke with MDHHS Worker about the incident. Per
MDHHS Worker’s case contact, Staff 1’s account of the situation
was consistent with her written statement and what was observed
in the video.
On 9/10/24 a phone interview with Staff 2 was completed by
DCWL. Staff 2 stated she was present after the incident, as
observed in the video. Staff 2 was around the corner from the
lounge door when she heard Staff 1 calling for help. Staff 2 saw
Youth A walking down the hallway, away from the lounge. When
Staff 2 entered the lounge, she observed Staff 1 standing by
Youth B. Youth B was unconscious, on the floor, with blood
around his face. Staff 2 called for assistance over the radio. After
a few moments Youth B got up and was assisted down the stairs,
where he was transported to the hospital. Staff 2 stated at the
time of the incident all youth were supposed to be in their rooms.
Youth B had been in and out of his room and repeatedly told to go
back to his room. Staff 2 was unaware that Youth A had gone into
the lounge. Staff 2 stated there were no incidents earlier that day
between the two youth that would have been a precursor to this
incident. Staff 2 asked Youth A why he attacked Youth B. Youth A
answered that Youth B “snitched” on him but did not give any
other details.
Video Reviewed
Staff 1 was sitting in a chair in the hallway, with her back to the
wall and her left side against the frame of the lounge doorway.
Youth B walked into the lounge, past Staff 1. The lounge was
dark, as the lights were not on. Youth A then walked into the
lounge, past Staff 1. Staff 1 did not turn to watch Youth A in the
room or turn the lights on. Youth B was standing in an area of the
room that could not be seen from where Staff 1 sat outside of the
doorway. Youth A immediately walked up to Youth B and put him
in a headlock from behind. Youth B began tapping Youth A’s arm.
Youth B swung Youth A around and continued choking him. Youth
5

B went limp after about five seconds. Youth A and Youth B had
been alone in the room for approximately twenty seconds before
Staff 1 entered. Staff 1 entered the room and tried to pull Youth
A’s arm from Youth B for fifteen seconds. Youth A then let go of
Youth B. Youth B dropped to the floor, unconscious, landing face
first. Youth A walked out of the room. Staff 1 went into the hallway
and appeared to be calling to someone, although the video did not
have audio. Staff 1 and Staff 2 entered the room and approached
Youth B on the floor. Youth C and Youth D entered the room, then
were immediately escorted out. Youth B stood up slowly, with
support from Staff 1 and Staff 2. Staff escorted Youth B out of the
room.
Documents Reviewed
• 7/11/24 Incident Report by Staff 1: “Directed all youth to get
ready for bed. I knew Youth B was in the lounge, and would
not come out. Youth A walked in the lounge, I heard a
strange sound. Went in and saw Youth B in a choke hold
by Youth A. Verbally directed him to let go twice. He
released Youth B the second time. Youth B fell hard, face
first to the floor. Blood puddle on the floor. Called for
Supervisor. Youth B got up, walked out of room. Took
Youth B to first floor, transported to hospital. Youth B
reported he and Youth A were horse playing.
• 7/12/24 written statement by Youth B: “I do not remember
anything other than playing around with Youth A. He got
me in a choke hold, then I passed out. He didn’t mean to
make me bleed. So I do not blame him. It was my fault for
not being in my room like I was supposed to.”
• 7/12/24 written statement by Youth A: “I accidentally
choked him (Youth B) out. We were rough housing around
and I held him for too long then staff redirected me multiple
times so I let go and he landed on his face.”
• 7/12/24 2:32AM- Ascension St. John Hospital discharge
report for Youth B indicated chipped tooth and stitches to
face.
• 7/12/24 4:25PM- Incident Report: Youth A stated he was
homicidal and that the hospital was a paid vacation. He
stated he only wanted to go for paperwork which would
cover him in case he actually breaks someone’s neck and
that would help him not go to jail.
• Line of sight policy for Wolverine Center: “An essential and
primary task of all program staff is to maintain adequate
supervision coverage and “Line of Sight’ of all clients when
in direct supervision of clients. Within the line of sight
6

means that it is possible to reasonably visually distinguish
and recognize individuals.”
• Staff 1’s human resources file held documentation that
Staff 1 completed orientation on 5/9/24, indicating she read
and agreed to follow agency policies including “line of sight
and positioning procedures”.
Analysis The facility is found to be in non-compliance, based on video
review and interviews with youth and staff. Staff 1 was aware that
two youth were alone in the lounge together, when they were not
supposed to be. Staff 1 did not maintain line of sight for both
youth. Being alone in the lounge provided Youth A the opportunity
to seriously physically assault Youth B.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2024C0001082SI dated 3/12/2024, CAP approved 4/11/2024.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
